'''Mark Nelson Chesnutt''' (born September 6, 1963) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Between 1990 and 1999, he had his greatest chart success recording for [[Universal Music Group Nashville]]'s [[MCA Records|MCA]] and [[Decca Records|Decca]] branches, with a total of eight albums between those two labels. During this timespan, Chesnutt also charted twenty top-ten hits on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, of which eight reached number one: "[[Brother Jukebox]]", "[[I'll Think of Something]]", "[[It Sure Is Monday]]", "[[Almost Goodbye (song)|Almost Goodbye]]", "[[I Just Wanted You to Know]]", "[[Gonna Get a Life]]", "[[It's a Little Too Late (Mark Chesnutt song)|It's a Little Too Late]]", and a cover of [[Aerosmith]]'s "[[I Don't Want to Miss a Thing]]". His first three albums for MCA (''[[Too Cold at Home]]'', ''[[Longnecks & Short Stories]]'', and ''[[Almost Goodbye]]'') along with a 1996 ''[[Greatest Hits (Mark Chesnutt album)|Greatest Hits]]'' package issued on Decca are all [[music recording sales certification|certified platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA); 1994's ''[[What a Way to Live]]'', also issued on Decca, is certified gold. After a self-titled album in 2002 on [[Columbia Records]], Chesnutt has continued to record predominantly on independent labels.

Chesnutt is known for his [[neotraditionalist country]] and [[honky-tonk]] influences, with frequent stylistic comparisons to [[George Jones]]. He has recorded several cover songs as both singles and album cuts, including covers of [[Hank Williams Jr.]], [[John Anderson (singer)|John Anderson]], [[Don Gibson]], [[Conway Twitty]], and [[Charlie Rich]]. Artists with whom he has collaborated include Jones, [[Tracy Byrd]], [[Vince Gill]], and [[Alison Krauss]]. [[Mark Wright (record producer)|Mark Wright]] produced all but one of his albums released in the 1990s, while his work since 2005 has been produced by [[Jimmy Ritchey]]. Chesnutt has also won two awards from the [[Country Music Association]]: the Horizon Award (now known as Best New Artist) and Vocal Event of the Year, both in 1993.

==Biography==
Mark Nelson Chesnutt was born on September 6, 1963, in [[Beaumont, Texas]].<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="whitburn"/> He drew musical influence from his father,  Bob Chesnutt, who was a singer and record collector.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112498649/ | title=Triple No. 1s fulfill Mark's dad's dream | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=July 27, 1991 | access-date=February 28, 2019 | author=Robert K. Oermann | pages=1D}}</ref> Chesnutt first played drums as a child after receiving a drum kit as a Christmas gift, but at his father's persuasion, he stopped playing drums and chose to focus on singing instead.<ref name="chron"/> He dropped out of school in the eleventh grade to begin playing in clubs around southeast Texas.<ref name="bubba"/> When he turned 17, his father began to take him to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to begin recording. For the next ten years, he began to record on small regional labels while he was the house band for local Beaumont nightclub Cutters.<ref name="allmusic"/> By the late 1980s, he had released eight singles, which would later be released together as an album titled ''Doing My Country Thing''.<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Greatest Hits|others=Mark Chesnut|year=1996|type=CD booklet|publisher=Decca Records|id=11529}}</ref> Record producer [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]] heard one of Chesnutt's independent releases,<ref name="cover"/> and recommended him to [[Mark Wright (record producer)|Mark Wright]], a songwriter, session musician, and record producer who helped Chesnutt sign with [[Universal Music Group Nashville|the Nashville branch]] of [[MCA Records]] in 1990.<ref name="hot cold">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112794120/ | title=Chesnutt's hot with 'Cold' | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=September 30, 1990 | access-date=March 20, 2019 | pages=38}}</ref> The same year, Bob Chesnutt died of a heart attack.<ref name="hurst"/>

==Musical career==
===''Too Cold at Home''===
Chesnutt released his major-label debut ''[[Too Cold at Home]]'' in 1990.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/mark-chesnutt-mn0000283405/biography|title=Mark Chesnutt biography|last=Huey|first=Steve|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=October 15, 2019}}</ref> It accounted for five chart singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. The first was "[[Too Cold at Home (song)|Too Cold at Home]]", written by Bobby Harden of [[The Harden Trio]].<ref name="hot cold"/> This song reached a peak of number three on ''Billboard'',<ref name="whitburn"/> while reaching number one on the country music charts published by ''[[Radio & Records]]'',<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/1990s/1991/RR-1991-02-01.PDF | title=R&R Country National Airplay | journal=[[Radio & Records]] | pages=57 |date=February 1, 1991}}</ref> ''[[Gavin Report]]'',<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Gavin-Report/90/91/Gavin-1991-01-25.pdf | title=Country | journal=[[Gavin Report]] | pages=32 |date=January 25, 1991}}</ref> and ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]''.<ref name="cover">{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Cash-Box/90s/1991/CB-1991-03-02.pdf | title=On the cover: Mark Chesnutt | author=Kimmy Wix | journal=[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]] | pages=2 |date=March 2, 1991}}</ref> The second single was "[[Brother Jukebox]]", which was written by [[Paul Craft]], originally released as a single by [[Don Everly]] of [[The Everly Brothers]] in 1977,<ref>Whitburn, p. 122</ref><ref name="whitburn"/> and also recorded by [[Keith Whitley]] on his 1989 album ''[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/i-wonder-do-you-think-of-me-mw0000201395 | title=''I Wonder Do You Think of Me'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=June 25, 2019}}</ref> Chesnutt's rendition of the song became his first number-one single on Hot Country Songs in 1991,<ref name="whitburn"/> while "[[Blame It on Texas]]", "[[Your Love Is a Miracle]]", and "[[Broken Promise Land]]" all peaked within the top ten of the same chart by year's end.<ref name="whitburn"/> "Broken Promise Land" was previously released by [[Waylon Jennings]] in 1986.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/80s/1986/BB-1986-12-27.pdf|title=Single Reviews|magazine=Billboard|date=December 27, 1986}}</ref> Contributing musicians to ''Too Cold at Home'' included [[Richard Bennett (guitarist)|Richard Bennett]], [[David Briggs (American musician)|David Briggs]], [[Mark O'Connor]], [[Hargus "Pig" Robbins]], [[Matt Rollings]], [[Brent Rowan]], and [[Glenn Worf]]. Wright produced the album and provided background vocals on some tracks. He also wrote or co-wrote five of its ten tracks including both "Blame It on Texas" and "Your Love Is a Miracle".<ref name="cold liner">{{cite AV media notes|title=Too Cold at Home|others=Mark Chesnutt|year=1990|type=CD booklet|publisher=MCA Records|id=10032}}</ref> Also included on the album was Chesnutt's rendition of "[[Friends in Low Places]]", which was released as a single in late 1990 by [[Garth Brooks]].<ref name="cold allmusic">{{cite news | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/too-cold-at-home-mw0000311006 | title=''Too Cold at Home'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 20, 2019 |author=Brian Mansfield |author-link=Brian Mansfield }}</ref>

''Too Cold at Home'' was met with generally positive critical and commercial reception. [[Alanna Nash]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' praised Chesnutt's singing voice and [[honky-tonk]] style, but felt that the album had too many cover songs.<ref name="nash cold">{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1990/12/07/too-cold-home/ | title=''Too Cold at Home'' and ''A Thousand Winding Roads'' | magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date=December 7, 1990 | access-date=March 20, 2019 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref> [[Brian Mansfield]] of [[AllMusic]] compared the album's sound to [[Western swing]] and [[George Jones]].<ref name="cold allmusic"/> In 1994, ''Too Cold at Home'' earned a [[music recording sales certification|platinum certification]] from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) for U.S. shipments of one million copies.<ref name="riaa">{{cite web | url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=mark+chesnutt#search_section | title=Search results for Mark Chesnutt | work=Recording Industry Association of America | access-date=April 5, 2019}}</ref> In addition, the [[Country Music Association]] nominated him for the 1991 Horizon Award (now known as Best New Artist).<ref name="cma"/>

===''Longnecks & Short Stories''===
Chesnutt's second album, 1992's ''[[Longnecks & Short Stories]]'', also earned a platinum certification.<ref name="riaa"/><ref name="whitburn"/> In order of release, its singles were "[[Old Flames Have New Names]]", "[[I'll Think of Something]]", "[[Bubba Shot the Jukebox]]", and "[[Ol' Country]]" (also written by Harden).<ref name="whitburn"/> "I'll Think of Something", previously a single for [[Hank Williams Jr.]] in 1974,<ref>Whitburn, pp. 398-399</ref> became Chesnutt's second number-one single on ''Billboard'' in 1992. The other three singles all made top ten on ''Billboard''.<ref name="whitburn"/> The album included many of the same session musicians as its predecessor, along with guest vocals from [[George Jones]] on "Talkin' to Hank", and both [[Alison Krauss]] and [[Vince Gill]] on "[[It's Not Over (Mark Chesnutt song)|It's Not Over]]".<ref name="long liner">{{cite AV media notes|title=Longnecks & Short Stories|others=Mark Chesnutt|year=1990|type=CD booklet|publisher=MCA Records|id=10530}}</ref> The latter was originally recorded by [[Reba McEntire]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/my-kind-of-country-mw0000197885|title=''My Kind of Country''|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=March 20, 2019}}</ref> while the closing track "Who Will the Next Fool Be?" was originally recorded by [[Charlie Rich]]. Chesnutt noted in a 1992 news article in ''[[The Tennessean]]'' that he was pleased to have recorded a duet with Jones, whom he considered a musical idol.<ref name="bubba">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112586649/ | title=Mark Chesnutt: One proud Bubba | work=The Tennessean | date=November 7, 1992 | access-date=March 20, 2019 | author=Robert K. Oermann | author-link=Robert K. Oermann | pages=1D, 2D}}</ref> He also noted that "Bubba Shot the Jukebox" (written by [[Dennis Linde]]) had been serviced "as a joke" by Nashville song promoters and was not taken seriously by other artists, but he felt that the song had potential.<ref name="hurst"/> The song was not originally intended to be a single, but was selected as one after a number of stations on the ''Billboard'' survey played the song frequently enough for it to enter the charts.<ref>{{cite magazine|date=August 15, 1992|title=Country Corner|magazine=Billboard|page=27|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1992/Billboard-1992-08-15.pdf}}</ref> Mansfield wrote in AllMusic that the album "heralded the emergence of a Texas voice that contained both the knack for humor... and the depth for heartache".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/longnecks-short-stories-mw0000610528 | title=''Longnecks & Short Stories'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 20, 2019}}</ref> Nash praised the song variety, highlighting the singles and "It's Not Over" in particular, but felt that Chesnutt's voice was "a little too laid back".<ref name="nash long">{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1992/04/03/longnecks-and-short-stories/ | title=''Longnecks & Short Stories'' | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=April 3, 1992 | access-date=March 20, 2019 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref>

===''Almost Goodbye''===
Chestnutt's third album for MCA was ''[[Almost Goodbye]]''. Released in 1993, it produced three straight number-one singles on Hot Country Singles & Tracks: "[[It Sure Is Monday]]" (also written by Linde), the [[Almost Goodbye (song)|title track]], and "[[I Just Wanted You to Know]]". The album's final single, a cover of [[Don Gibson]]'s 1972 single "[[Woman (Sensuous Woman)]]", was less successful on the charts.<ref name="whitburn"/> The album also became his third to be certified platinum.<ref name="riaa"/> Mansfield wrote of the album in AllMusic that "Weak material weighs down Chesnutt's third release, though he still sings them like the most romantic [[western swing]]er since [[George Strait]]." He praised the title track for its [[string section]], but criticized the uptempo material as being inferior to "Bubba Shot the Jukebox" and "Old Flames Have New Names".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/almost-goodbye-mw0000103211 | title=''Almost Goodbye'' | publisher=Allmusic | access-date=March 25, 2019}}</ref> Nash felt that the album was "class-A honky-tonk, ballad, and Texas swing, delivered by a guy whose instincts are usually as sure as his pitch", but criticized the lyrics of the closing track "The Will".<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1993/06/25/almost-goodbye/ | title=''Almost Goodbye'' | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=June 25, 1993 | access-date=March 25, 2019}}</ref> Also in 1993, Chesnutt won two awards from the Country Music Association: the Horizon Award, and Vocal Event of the Year for George Jones' 1992 single "[[I Don't Need Your Rockin' Chair]]", which featured Chesnutt as one of several guest vocalists and was awarded to all participants on the song.<ref name="cma">{{cite web | url=https://cmaawards.com/past-winners-and-nominees/?appSession=0Q0IQ3PM0KZ9QO1816U7L77U01N8558WSY2Q9QD4O9RRD528NKVOF6U90E70WZ357L93X480WW79HO7VA3G47I0QE6F925PAM539M5F3X569JQU718ZWS872M9NIKIQP | title=Search Results | work=Country Music Association | access-date=March 20, 2019}}</ref> Following the success of ''Almost Goodbye'', Chesnutt embarked on his first headlining tours in 1994, a move which Chesnutt later said inspired him to focus more on songwriting due to the minimal profitability from touring.<ref name="bonna">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112812759 | title=Mark Chesnutt: This no. 1 artist remembers life in honky-tonk joints | work=The Tennessean | date=July 6, 1995 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Bonna M. de la Cruz | pages=1, 2}}</ref>

===''What a Way to Live''===
[[File:Mark Chesnutt, 2010.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Chesnutt performing at [[Camp Humphreys]] in 2010.|alt=Country music singer Mark Chesnutt singing and strumming a guitar.]]
In 1994, MCA revived the Nashville branch of [[Decca Records]] and moved Chesnutt to it.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112764662/ | title=Shipley wants to be judged on deeds | work=The Tennessean | date=April 24, 1994 | access-date=March 25, 2019 | author=Tom Roland | pages=2E}}</ref> His first Decca album, ''[[What a Way to Live]]'', came out that year. The album included four singles: "[[She Dreams]]", "[[Goin' Through the Big D]]", 
"[[Gonna Get a Life]]", and "[[Down in Tennessee]]".<ref name="whitburn"/> Of these, "She Dreams" was previously a single in 1993 for its co-writer [[Tim Mensy]],<ref>Whitburn, p. 238</ref> while "Down in Tennessee" was previously a single for [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]] in 1985.<ref>Whitburn, pp. 23-24</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1995/BB-1995-06-17.pdf | title=Country Corner | author=Wade Jessen | magazine=Billboard |date=June 17, 1995 | pages=32}}</ref> "Gonna Get a Life" was the most successful of the singles, reaching the top of the ''Billboard'' country charts in 1995.<ref name="whitburn"/> Two other cover songs were included on the album as well: the [[What a Way to Live (song)|title track]] was originally recorded by [[Willie Nelson]] in 1960, while a cover of [[Waylon Jennings]]' 1974 single "[[Rainy Day Woman]]" included Jennings on duet vocals and lead guitar.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112815204/ | title=Spotlight | work=The Tennessean | date=July 7, 1995 | access-date=March 25, 2019 | pages=1}}</ref><ref name="believe">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113133102 | title=Hitting it big: Mark Chesnutt can't believe he's part of star lineup | work=The Tennessean | date=June 10, 1994 | access-date=March 25, 2019 | author=Tom Wood | pages=1, 2}}</ref> Chesnutt said that he chose to record the Jennings cover at the suggestion of his managers while listening to Jennings' albums on his tour bus, and that Wright was responsible for making arrangements for Jennings to appear on the song.<ref name="bonna"/> The album received a positive review from David Zimmerman of Gannett News Service, who praised the variety of traditional-leaning country sounds and Chesnutt's singing voice.<ref name="zimm">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/205915486/ | title=Chesnutt album comes close to perfect | work=Battle Creek Enquirer | date=September 29, 1994 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=David Zimmerman | pages=2}}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of AllMusic was less favorable, stating that the album "is dogged by inconsistent material, but Chesnutt's fine singing manages to save most of the weaker material from being a bore."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/what-a-way-to-live-mw0000119108 | title=''What a Way to Live'' | publisher=Allmusic | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Stephen Thomas Erlewine}}</ref> ''What a Way to Live'' earned a gold certification from the RIAA in 1995 for shipments of 500,000 copies.<ref name="riaa"/>

===''Wings'' and ''Greatest Hits''===
His next album, ''[[Wings (Mark Chesnutt album)|Wings]]'', came out in 1995. For this album, Tony Brown served as producer instead of Wright.<ref name="cst wings"/> According to Chesnutt, he chose a different producer because Wright had wanted to push him to a more [[country pop]] style, a change with which Chesnutt disagreed.<ref name="promise">{{cite journal| title=Chesnutt keeps his promise | journal=Country Standard Time | date=February 1997}} [http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=345 Page 1] [http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/articlex.asp?xid=345&p=2 page 2]</ref> Chesnutt noted that the album was completed more quickly than his previous ones: while the others took an average of two months to complete due to him having to schedule recording sessions around tour dates, he was able to complete ''Wings'' in only ten consecutive days. He also took most of April and May 1995 off from touring, and resumed in June on a tour that also featured [[Brooks & Dunn]].<ref name="bonna"/> Contributing songwriters on ''Wings'' included [[Jim Lauderdale]] and [[Mack Vickery]].<ref name="bb wings">{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rA4EAAAAMBAJ | title=Reviews | magazine=Billboard | date=28 October 1995 | pages=87}}</ref> The first single was a cover of [[Todd Snider]]'s "[[Trouble (Todd Snider song)|Trouble]]",<ref name="nash wings">{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1995/10/20/wings-5/ | title=''Wings'' | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=October 20, 1995 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref> which Chesnutt took to Top 20 of Hot Country Songs in 1995.<ref name="whitburn"/> The album's second single, "[[It Wouldn't Hurt to Have Wings]]", was a top-ten country hit, while followup "[[Wrong Place, Wrong Time]]" was less successful on the charts.<ref name="whitburn"/> Also included on the album was a cover of Hank Williams Jr.'s 1972 hit "Pride's Not Hard to Swallow."<ref name="cst wings"/> Chesnutt co-wrote the track "As the Honky Tonk Turns", which he said was inspired by his early days singing in honky-tonk bars and observing the crowds.<ref name="bonna"/> Rick Mitchell in ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music'' described it as a "honky-tonk concept album" that "bucked the commercial trend toward throwaway novelty tunes and lightweight country-pop."<ref name="encyclopedia"/> The album received largely positive reviews from publications such as ''[[Country Standard Time]]'', ''Billboard'', and AllMusic, all of which praised the songwriting quality and honky-tonk stylings of the music, with the former two publications also considering it among the strongest album releases of the year.<ref name="cst wings">{{cite web | url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1892 | title=''Wings'' review | work=Country Standard Time | access-date=March 25, 2019 | author=Jeffrey B. Remz}}</ref><ref name="bb wings"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/wings-mw0000179882 | title=''Wings'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Stephen Thomas Erlewine}}</ref>

Decca issued a [[Greatest Hits (Mark Chesnutt album)|''Greatest Hits'']] package in 1996.<ref name="allmusic"/> This album reprised ten of his biggest hits and included two new songs in "[[It's a Little Too Late (Mark Chesnutt song)|It's a Little Too Late]]" and "[[Let It Rain (Mark Chesnutt song)|Let It Rain]]"; both were released as singles, with the former becoming a number-one single on ''Billboard'' in 1997.<ref name="whitburn"/> At the time of this compilation's release, Chesnutt stated that he had toured almost nonstop for the past six years, and that he had wanted to take longer breaks between touring but was unable to since his album sales were not as strong as those of his contemporaries.<ref name="hurst">{{cite web | url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1996-12-08-9612080047-story.html | title=Road Warrior | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | date=December 8, 1996 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Jack Hurst}}</ref> Four years after its release, ''Greatest Hits'' became Chesnutt's fourth and final platinum album.<ref name="riaa"/>

===''Thank God for Believers''===
In 1997, Chesnutt released ''[[Thank God for Believers]]'', which reunited him with Wright on production duties.<ref name="thank"/> Of their reunion, Wright said that he felt that both of them were "on a downslide" prior to ''Wings'', while Chesnutt said that "Mark and I kind of got away from each other for awhile because we needed it. We both lost a little bit of what we started together" and that, once the two started working together, "It was like we were never apart."<ref name="promise"/> The album also featured several songs penned by [[Roger Springer]], with whom Chesnutt soon developed a friendship and songwriting relationship.<ref name="promise"/> This album's [[Thank God for Believers (song)|title track]], which also served as the lead single, ascended to the number two position on the Hot Country Singles & Tracks charts by the end of 1997.<ref name="whitburn"/> While finishing the album, Chesnutt and Wright chose to include the same recording of "It's Not Over" that had previously appeared on ''Longnecks & Short Stories'' to replace a song that the two felt did not fit with the rest of the album. "It's Not Over" was sent out as the second single from ''Thank God for Believers'' due to demand from radio listeners. Chesnutt agreed to release the song because he felt it had potential as a single, and he was "disappointed" that it had not been a single from its original album.<ref name="over">{{cite magazine|last=Taylor|first=Chuck|date=10 January 1998|title=For Country's Mark Chesnutt, Reviving an Earlier Song Shows It Wasn't Over|magazine=Billboard|page=78}}</ref> Two more singles followed in 1998: "[[I Might Even Quit Lovin' You]]" and "Wherever You Are".<ref name="whitburn"/> Nash called the album "a sometimes stunning reminder of the singer’s first-rate, smooth-as-bourbon interpretive style".<ref name="thank">{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1997/09/26/thank-god-believers/ | title=''Thank God for Believers'' | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=September 26, 1997 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref> Thom Owens wrote in AllMusic that the album was "strong, thoroughly enjoyable modern country."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/thank-god-for-believers-mw0000026677 | title=Thank God for Believers | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Thom Owens}}</ref>

===''I Don't Want to Miss a Thing''===
[[File:Aerosmith2007.jpg|250px|thumb|Chesnutt topped the country music charts in early 1999 with a cover of "[[I Don't Want to Miss a Thing]]", originally recorded by the rock band [[Aerosmith]] (pictured here in 2007).|alt=Rock band Aerosmith performing on stage]]
In late 1998, Chesnutt recorded a cover version of [[Aerosmith]]'s "[[I Don't Want to Miss a Thing]]" at the suggestion of Wright, who had heard the song on his car radio. Because the two thought that the song had potential as a single, Decca withdrew promotion of "Wherever You Are" in favor of the cover,<ref name="thing">{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KQoEAAAAMBAJ | title=Decca's Chesnutt Does Rock 'Thing' | author=Deborah Evans Price | magazine=Billboard | pages=30, 32 |date=December 19, 1998}}</ref> which resulted in "Wherever You Are" becoming his first single not to make top 40 on the country music charts.<ref name="whitburn"/> Chesnutt said that he decided to cover the song because he felt that, despite his chart successes, he "wasn't getting noticed" due to the weaker sales of his last two albums compared to his first three. He felt that covering a pop song would "show people [he] could sing something other than the same old stuff", while also noting that many of his previous successful songs had been ballads.<ref name="sculley"/> By early 1999, his version of "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing" had reached the top of the Hot Country Singles & Tracks charts; it was also his first entry on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], where it ascended to No. 17.<ref name="whitburn"/> Despite showing favor toward the cover song at the time, he later expressed disdain for recording it; he told the blog Taste of Country in 2018 that he did not think that it fit his established style, that neither the single nor the corresponding album sold well despite the song's success at radio, and that he had refused offers from the label to release another cover of a pop song.<ref name="sounds"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/mark-chesnutt-song-that-made-george-jones-mad/ | title=Mark Chesnutt reveals what made George Jones mad at him | work=[[Taste of Country]] | date=September 6, 2018 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Sterling Whitaker}}</ref> The corresponding album, also titled ''[[I Don't Want to Miss a Thing (album)|I Don't Want to Miss a Thing]]'', went on to account for only one other single in "[[This Heartache Never Sleeps]]". which reached top 20 on the country music charts.<ref name="whitburn"/> Nash wrote of the album that the cover was "a bit of a jolt", but added that Chesnutt "goes on to find enough snappy rhythm tunes and scampering Western swing to keep the toes tapping."<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1999/03/05/i-dont-want-miss-thing/ | title=''I Don't Want to Miss a Thing'' | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=March 5, 1999 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref> An uncredited review from ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine praised Chesnutt's singing voice and the "good and varied songs".<ref name="people">{{cite web | url=https://people.com/archive/picks-and-pans-review-i-dont-want-to-miss-a-thing-vol-51-no-6/ | title=Picks and Pans Review: I Don't Want to Miss a Thing | work=People | date=February 15, 1999 | access-date=March 26, 2019}}</ref>

===''Lost in the Feeling''===
In January 1999, MCA Nashville dissolved the Decca Nashville division. While most of the artists were dropped, Chesnutt was one of only three to move back to MCA, alongside [[Lee Ann Womack]] and [[Gary Allan]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113481975 | title=Shakeup swallows Decca | work=The Tennessean | date=January 22, 1999 | access-date=March 25, 2019 | author=Jay Orr, Tom Roland | pages=1A, 2A}}</ref> MCA released his album ''[[Lost in the Feeling (Mark Chesnutt album)|Lost in the Feeling]]'' in October 2000. The album included covers of two songs co-written and originally recorded by [[Shawn Camp (musician)|Shawn Camp]] on his 1993 [[Shawn Camp (album)|self-titled debut album]], which was also produced by Wright: "[[Fallin' Never Felt So Good]]" and "[[Confessin' My Love]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://roughstock.com/news/2010/09/19131-shawn-camp-shawn-camp|title=''Shawn Camp'' review|last=Peacock|first=Bobby|work=Roughstock|date=28 September 2010|access-date=March 26, 2019}}</ref><ref>Whitburn, p. 67</ref> Also covered on the album were the [[Lost in the Feeling (song)|title track]], previously a single for [[Conway Twitty]] in 1983,<ref>Whitburn, pp. 372-373</ref> and [[Gene Watson]]'s 1975 single "[[Love in the Hot Afternoon]]".<ref name="lost allmusic"/><ref>Whitburn, p. 386</ref> "Fallin' Never Felt So Good" and "Lost in the Feeling" were both issued as singles, but neither made Top 40 of the country music charts.<ref name="whitburn"/> A review in ''Billboard'' was positive, stating that "seldom has he packed more authority and emotion into a recording", highlighting the cover songs in particular.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uRAEAAAAMBAJ | title=Reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=25, 26 |date=November 4, 2000}}</ref> Maria Konicki Dinoia of AllMusic also showed favor toward the cover songs while comparing Chesnutt's voice to that of [[Merle Haggard]].<ref name="lost allmusic">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/lost-in-the-feeling-mw0000101113 | title=''Lost in the Feeling'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 27, 2019}}</ref> ''Lost in the Feeling'' was commercially unsuccessful,<ref name="allmusic"/> and Chesnutt was dropped from MCA's roster one month after the album's release.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5RAEAAAAMBAJ | title=Nashville Scene | author=Phyllis Stark | magazine=Billboard | pages=39 |date=November 11, 2000}}</ref> Despite not being on a label at the time, he sang duet vocals on [[Tracy Byrd]]'s early-2001 single "[[A Good Way to Get on My Bad Side]]", from Byrd's album ''[[Ten Rounds (Tracy Byrd album)|Ten Rounds]]''.<ref name="whitburn"/>

===''Mark Chesnutt''===
Chesnutt signed to [[Columbia Records]] in 2002 for the release of his [[Mark Chesnutt (album)|self-titled]] studio album. The lead single "[[She Was]]" went to number 11 on Hot Country Singles & Tracks and number 62 on the Hot 100, while the followup singles "I Want My Baby Back" and "I'm in Love with a Married Woman" did not reach Top 40 of the former.<ref name="whitburn"/> To promote the album, Chesnutt went on a 75-date tour known as the Rockin' Roadhouse Tour, which also featured [[Joe Diffie]] and [[Tracy Lawrence]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/76769/rockin-roadhouse-tour-sets-first-round-of-dates | title=Rockin' Roadhouse Tour Sets First Round Of Dates | magazine=Billboard | date=February 15, 2002 | access-date=March 27, 2019}}</ref> [[Billy Joe Walker Jr.]] produced the album, and contributing musicians included [[Aubrey Haynie]], [[Brent Mason]], and [[Dan Dugmore]].<ref name="cooper">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113606261/ | title=Chesnutt swings back to the country tree | work=The Tennessean | date=May 27, 2002 | access-date=March 27, 2019 | author=Peter Cooper | pages=7D}}</ref> Both William Ruhlmann of AllMusic and Peter Cooper of ''The Tennessean'' criticized the album for weak songwriting,<ref name="cooper"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/mark-chesnutt-mw0000222101 | title=''Mark Chesnutt'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 27, 2019}}</ref> while John Lupton of ''Country Standard Time'' felt that the album was "about average for him, but...it's an average that's usually a cut above."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1888 | title=''Mark Chesnutt'' review | work=Country Standard Time | access-date=March 27, 2019 | author=John Lupton}}</ref> Chesnutt later stated that he quickly left Columbia Records because executives had pressured him into recording more modern-sounding [[country pop]] instead of his traditional style, a concern that he had also had during his latter years at MCA.<ref name="reno"/>

===''Savin' the Honky Tonk'' and ''Heard It in a Love Song''===
Chesnutt's eleventh album, ''[[Savin' the Honky Tonk]]'', was released in 2004 via the independent Vivaton! label.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/244488681/ | title=Local business in brief | work=The Tennessean | date=May 8, 2004 | access-date=March 27, 2019 | pages=3E}}</ref> [[Jimmy Ritchey]] was the album's producer,<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/00s/2004/BB-2004-10-09.pdf | title=Reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=40 |date=October 9, 2004}}</ref> and one of several contributing songwriters along with Chesnutt, [[Jerry Salley]], [[Dean Miller]], [[Jason Sellers]], and [[Kevin Fowler]].<ref name="savin"/> Chesnutt said that he intended for the album to be a return to the honky-tonk sounds of his earlier albums, and felt that being on an independent label allowed for him to record music that he wanted to record, as opposed to being pressured into recording songs that were forced upon him by major-label executives.<ref name="reno">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/152774828/ | title=Honky-tonkin' Chesnutt swears off pop ballads | work=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]] | date=May 26, 2005 | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Neil Baron | pages=22}}</ref> The album accounted for three singles: "The Lord Loves the Drinkin' Man", "I'm a Saint", and "A Hard Secret to Keep".<ref name="whitburn"/> Erlewine said of the album that "Chesnutt not only sounds comfortable and relaxed, he's re-energized, both by the straight-ahead setting and the freedom to pick songs without an eye on the airwaves."<ref name="savin">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/savin-the-honky-tonk-mw0000395095 | title=''Savin' the Honky Tonk'' | work=AllMusic | access-date=March 27, 2019 | author=Stephen Thomas Erlewine}}</ref> Robert Loy of ''Country Standard Time'' considered the disc a [[concept album]], noting the unifying theme of alcohol consumption in most of the songs.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1887 | title=''Savin' the Honky Tonk'' | work=Country Standard Time | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Robert Loy}}</ref> Chesnutt toured small venues in 2004 and 2005 in support of the album.<ref name="reno"/>

''[[Heard It in a Love Song (album)|Heard It in a Love Song]]'' followed in 2006 on CBuJ Records.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1541790/chesnutt-releases-heard-it-in-a-love-song/|title=Chesnutt Releases Heard It in a Love Song|work=CMT|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190328230916/http://www.cmt.com/news/1541790/chesnutt-releases-heard-it-in-a-love-song/|archive-date=2019-03-28|access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> Its [[Heard It in a Love Song|title track]] was previously a pop hit for [[The Marshall Tucker Band]], and many of the other songs on the album were covers as well, including [[Charley Pride]]'s "[[A Shoulder to Cry On (Charley Pride song)|A Shoulder to Cry On]]" and [[Hank Williams]]'s "[[Lost Highway (Leon Payne song)|Lost Highway]]".<ref name="dispatch">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/151881081/ | title=Jackson's not afraid to sing the blues; Strait sticks with what comes naturally | work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] | date=October 24, 2006 | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Barry Gilbert | pages=D1, D3}}</ref> Barry Gilbert of the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' rated the album "B", praising Chesnutt's singing voice and the contrast of the title track with the other cover songs.<ref name="dispatch"/> Mark Deming of AllMusic stated that "while ''Heard It in a Love Song'' lacks the hard country feel of [''Savin' the Honky Tonk''], it's a solid set that confirms the man's musical instincts are back on track."<ref name="heard">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/heard-it-in-a-love-song-mw0000449318 | title=''Heard It in a Love Song'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 27, 2019 | author=Mark Deming}}</ref>

===''Rollin' with the Flow'' and ''Outlaw''===
Chesnutt signed to [[Lofton Creek Records]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1563710/mark-chesnutt-signs-to-lofton-creek/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171101014655/http://www.cmt.com/news/1563710/mark-chesnutt-signs-to-lofton-creek/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=November 1, 2017 | title=Mark Chesnutt Signs to Lofton Creek | work=CMT | date=June 28, 2007 | access-date=March 27, 2019}}</ref> His only disc for the label was ''[[Rollin' with the Flow (album)|Rollin' with the Flow]]'', the [[Rollin' with the Flow|title track]] of which was a number-one single on the country charts for [[Charlie Rich]] in 1977. Chesnutt's version reached number 25 on the same chart in late 2007-early 2008, and "She Never Got Me Over You" made the charts as well.<ref name="whitburn"/> The album once again featured Jimmy Ritchey as producer, with contributing musicians including [[Glenn Worf]], [[Brent Mason]], [[Eddie Bayers]], and [[Lonnie Wilson]]. Ritchey also co-wrote several songs on the album.<ref name="rollin"/> Mark Deming of AllMusic wrote of the album that it was "as solid an album as Chesnutt's ever recorded — which is saying plenty."<ref name="rollin">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/rollin-with-the-flow-mw0000785522 | title=''Rollin' with the Flow'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Mark Deming}}</ref> Writing for ''Roughstock'', Matt Bjorke said that it was "the kind of record that traditionalist country fans dream about. It has something for all those fans", highlighting Chesnutt's vocal delivery on the title track in particular.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2008/06/21833-mark-chesnutt-rollin-with-the-flow | title=''Rollin' with the Flow'' | work=Roughstock | date=June 23, 2008 | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Matt Bjorke}}</ref>

In 2010, Chesnutt announced the release of his next studio album, ''[[Outlaw (Mark Chesnutt album)|Outlaw]]''. The album includes covers of songs by [[outlaw country]] artists, including [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Hank Williams Jr.]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Billy Joe Shaver]], [[David Allan Coe]], and [[Jerry Jeff Walker]]. According to Chesnutt, he was presented the idea by record producer [[Pete Anderson]], best known for his work with [[Dwight Yoakam]], when Saguaro Road Records was seeking an artist to perform a covers album. The two recorded the album at Anderson's studio in [[Burbank, California]], in only two days. To support the album, he toured with [[Tracy Lawrence]] and [[Richie McDonald]] (of [[Lonestar]]) on the Country Rat Pack Tour.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1644549/mark-chesnutt-tips-hat-to-his-heroes-in-outlaw/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171101014355/http://www.cmt.com/news/1644549/mark-chesnutt-tips-hat-to-his-heroes-in-outlaw/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=November 1, 2017 | title=Mark Chesnutt Tips Hat to His Heroes in Outlaw | work=CMT | date=July 27, 2010 | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Edward Morris}}</ref> Thom Jurek referred to the album as "a no-frills, solid, lean, mean, rocking, emotionally sincere tribute to the outlaw generation, which is, in many ways, an extension of Chesnutt's own persona."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/outlaw-mw0001996770 | title=''Outlaw'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref>

===''Live From The Big D'', ''Greatest Hits II'', and ''Tradition Lives''===
Chesnutt formed his own label, Nada Dinero, in 2012. His first release through this label was a live album called ''Live from the Big D'', recorded in [[Dallas, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.1011now.com/content/news/Country-star-Mark-Chesnutt-headlining-Saline-County-Fair-385475261.html | title=Country star Mark Chesnutt headlining Saline County Fair | work=1011now.com | date=July 4, 2016 | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> This was followed by a second Greatest Hits package in 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bear-family.com/chesnutt-mark-greatest-hits-ii.html | title=Mark Chesnutt Greatest Hits II | work=Bear Family Records | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> The album accounted for one single, "When the Lights Go Out (Tracie's Song)".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://daily.plaympe.com/mark-chesnutt-when-the-lights-go-out-tracies-song-single/|title=Mark Chesnutt - When The Lights Go Out (Tracie's Song) (Single)|work=Daily Play MPE|date=April 22, 2013}}</ref>

Chesnutt continued to tour throughout the 2010s. In 2013, [[George Jones]] invited Chesnutt to be his opener on the last show of his farewell tour at [[Bridgestone Arena]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. However, Jones died before the show could take place, so Chesnutt and other artists held a tribute show in Jones's honor instead.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://thesouthern.com/entertainment/music/mark-chesnutt-brings-hard-core-country-to-benton/article_59a16ebe-8c1d-5bc4-991a-5f8789c1b749.html | title=Mark Chesnutt brings hard-core country to Benton | work=The Southern Illinoisan | date=November 26, 2015 | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> His next studio album, ''[[Tradition Lives]]'', came out in 2016.<ref name="allmusic"/> Included on the album was a cover of [[Merle Haggard]]'s "There Won't Be Another Now", from his 1985 album ''[[Kern River (album)|Kern River]]''. According to Chesnutt, the cover was something that Ritchey and Chesnutt had done for fun, without the intention of ever putting it on an album, due to it being one of Chesnutt's favorite Merle Haggard songs. As Haggard died just before the album's release, they chose to include it as a tribute to him. Of the album's sound, Chesnutt remarked that "I wanted to show the world that I’m still here and that I’m still Country. I’m not changing with the times."<ref name="sounds">{{cite web | url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/mark-chesnutt-looking-backand-looking-forward/ | title=Mark Chesnutt: Looking back... and looking forward | work=Sounds Like Nashville | date=July 14, 2016 | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Chuck Dauphin}}</ref> Erlewine noted the "simple, spare, and easy" production of the album, and thought that it was similar in sound to Chesnutt's earlier albums.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/tradition-lives-mw0002948903 | title=''Tradition Lives'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 28, 2019 | author=Stephen Thomas Erlewine}}</ref>

==Additional contributions==
In 1993, Chesnutt was featured in an ad campaign for [[Frito-Lay]] where he sang their tagline "I know what I like and I like [[Fritos]]."<ref>{{cite news |title=Farming Today |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1993/05/27/Farming-Today/1471738475200/ |access-date=10 August 2021 |work=UPI |date=27 May 1993 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Fritos brand Product History |url=http://fritolay.com/consumer.html |website=FritoLay |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20001212183900/http://fritolay.com/consumer.html |archive-date=12 December 2000}}</ref> In 1994, he contributed three cover songs to multi-artist compilation albums. These were [[Merle Haggard]]'s "Goodbye Comes Hard for Me", recorded for the [[AIDS]] benefit album ''[[Red Hot + Country]]'';<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/red-hot-country-mw0000622534 | title=''Red Hot + Country'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 25, 2019}}</ref> [[Keith Whitley]]'s "I Never Go Around Mirrors (I've Got a Heartache to Hide)" to ''[[Keith Whitley: A Tribute Album]]'';<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/keith-whitley-tribute-mw0000119114 | title=''Keith Whitley: A Tribute Album'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> and "Good Ones and Bad Ones", a duet with George Jones on the latter's 1994 duets album ''[[The Bradley Barn Sessions]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/bradley-barn-sessions-mw0000119727 | title=''The Bradley Barn Sessions'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> In 1996, the radio station [[WKIS]] in [[Boca Raton, Florida]], compiled a Christmas album titled ''A Country Christmas from WKIS 99.9'', to which Chesnutt contributed a recording of the Christmas carol "[[What Child Is This?]]"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/country-christmas-from-kiss-999-mw0000069481 | title=''A Country Christmas from WKIS 99.9'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> His version made the Hot Country Songs charts that same year due to seasonal airplay.<ref name="whitburn"/>

==Musical style and influences==
Chesnutt's musical style draws mainly from [[honky-tonk]] and [[neotraditional country]].<ref name="allmusic"/> Due to both singers hailing from Beaumont, Chesnutt was frequently compared stylistically to George Jones.<ref name="bubba"/> Jack Hurst of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' wrote that he was "a throwback to the inwardly-tough, just-do-it kind of country star they were making back when they minted George Jones, who preceded Chesnutt out of the rough-and-tumble East Texas honky-tonks 40 years ago."<ref name="hurst"/> Nash described Chesnutt's vocal style by saying that he "has a comely, smooth baritone and a supple way of moving through his vocal range",<ref name="nash cold"/> and a "friendly foghorn" with "earnestness".<ref name="nash long"/> Rick Mitchell, writing in ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music'', described Chesnutt as "arguably the strongest pure-country voice to come out of Southeastern Texas since George Jones",<ref name="encyclopedia">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=untabCgOVkgC | title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music | year=1998 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780199770557 |editor=John Rumble, Paul Kingsbury | pages=92}}</ref> and an uncredited review in ''People'' said that Chesnutt "has a natural, George Jonesian sob and enough machismo to get away with going falsetto when he wants."<ref name="people"/> Chesnutt has cited [[Merle Haggard]], [[Hank Williams]], and [[Elvis Presley]] as major influences of his.<ref name="encyclopedia"/> Mitchell also noted that Chesnutt was able to have success with both ballads and uptempo material such as "Bubba Shot the Jukebox" and "Old Flames Have New Names", as well as the strong presence of cover songs from the 1950s and 1960s. Some of his songs, such as "It Sure Is Monday" and "Gonna Get a Life", have featured influences of [[Cajun music]] through prominent use of fiddle and accordion.<ref name="encyclopedia"/>

Chesnutt's musical persona placed a greater emphasis on song quality over physical attractiveness, compared to the move toward young and attractive males that prevailed in country music in the 1990s. Nash stated that he "distanced himself from the pack with an identifiable baritone and a focus on music over image",<ref name="nash wings"/> and Barry Gilbert of the ''St. Louis Post-Dispatch'' similarly stated that he "put the music and his warm, classic-country voice before the image."<ref name="dispatch"/> Chesnutt stated in a 1996 interview that "I would rather play honky-tonks the rest of my life for $500 a week than be something I'm not."<ref name="hurst"/> He noted that during his latter years at Decca and MCA, he was constantly pressured by label heads to record more mainstream-friendly country pop instead of the traditional sounds of his earlier albums, due to the genre's shift away from neotraditional country having a negative impact on his album sales.<ref name="chron">{{cite web | url=https://www.chron.com/entertainment/article/Mark-Chesnutt-breaks-out-with-Outlaw-1597251.php | title=Mark Chesnutt breaks out with Outlaw | work=Houston Chronicle | date=June 28, 2010 | access-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref> He also said that some of the tracks on ''Savin' the Honky Tonk'' were songs that the major labels had rejected, and that he would "rather sell 100,000 albums [of traditional country] than 6 million of some crap that I wasn't happy with."<ref name="reno"/>

==Personal life==
Chesnutt has been married to the former Tracie Motley since 1992. The two met in a bar, and according to Chesnutt, "She came out there with a guy she was with at the time, and I took her away from him".<ref name="hurst"/> The couple have three sons: Waylon, Casey, and Cameron.<ref name="sculley">{{cite web | url=https://www.mcall.com/news/mc-xpm-1999-08-08-3264684-story.html | title=It's more than a tradition thing for country's mark Chesnutt | work=The Morning Call | date=August 8, 1999 | access-date=March 26, 2019 | author=Alan Sculley}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.zanesvilletimesrecorder.com/story/news/local/2016/03/24/mark-chesnutt-play-smiling-goat/82208708/ | title=Mark Chesnutt to play Smiling Goat | work=Zanesville Times Recorder | date=March 24, 2016 | access-date=March 26, 2019}}</ref> Waylon was named after Waylon Jennings, who jokingly suggested during the recording sessions for their cover of "Rainy Day Woman" that the then-pregnant Tracie name their child after him. Although Jennings later stated that the suggestion was a joke, Chesnutt decided to choose the name anyway.<ref name="bonna"/> In late 1995, following Waylon Chesnutt's birth, Tracie typically stayed home at the couple's house in [[Jasper, Texas]], while also working as an artist.<ref name="bonna"/> The birth of his sons also caused Chesnutt to tour less frequently by the end of the 1990s, as he wanted to be able to spend more time with his family.<ref name="sculley"/>

===Health===
In October 2021, Chesnutt announced that he would be taking a hiatus from touring until 2022 in order to recover from back surgery.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=12007 | title=Chesnutt cancels all '21 shows, needs more time off after surgery | publisher=Country Standard Time | date=October 13, 2021 | access-date=October 13, 2021}}</ref> On November 1, 2023, Chesnutt was hospitalized for an issue that required critical care, and underwent multiple tests to determine the exact problem. Several of his concerts were canceled, but his condition was reported as stable.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/mark-chesnutt-hospitalized/ | title=Update: Mark Chesnutt Hospitalized | date=3 November 2023 }}</ref> He canceled further shows in June 2024 after being hospitalized again for an emergency [[quadruple bypass surgery]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2024/06/18/mark-chesnutt-hospitalized-after-undergoing-emergency-heart-surgery-cancels-upcoming-shows/ | title=Mark Chesnutt Hospitalized After Undergoing Emergency Heart Surgery, Cancels Upcoming Shows | publisher=Whiskey Riff | date=June 18, 2024 | accessdate=June 19, 2024}}</ref>
